body: A COOK should always say yes when offered something that will ''stink up your pot real good.'' It's a lesson I learned earlier this month, when James Graham handed me a couple of pieces of seasoning meat from his truck, parked on a stretch of asphalt in Brooklyn. Seasoning meat is really just the thick trimmings band-sawed from the top or bottom of
title: Brooklyn's Flavor Route to the South

body: When Adrienne Johnson reached the fifth-floor stairwell of the north tower of the World Trade Center during her 37-floor descent on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, she saw a man with white hair and sparkling blue eyes. ''He was smiling the whole time,'' she recalled. ''I say to this day that he must have been an angel. He said, 'Don't worry, you're
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Years After a Close Escape on Sept. 11, A Woman Faces a Calamity All Her Own

body: THERE are many spectacles in New York every December, from the Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center to Bergdorf Goodman's fantastical windows. But of special interest are the holiday markets that pop up all over the city, from Grand Central Terminal to Union Square, with hundreds of artisans and retailers selling unusual gifts. One of them is Lotta
title: SHOPPING WITH LOTTA ANDERSON; Handy for the Holidays

body: MARY COLE lives in an old wood-frame house, all yellow paint and green trim. It has a peaked roof with a tall chimney. Set back from the street on a small hill, her home feels private and peaceful. ''It resonates of the past -- books you've read, movies you've seen,'' Ms. Cole said. ''This house looks like a children's drawing of a house. It's a
title: Forgotten by Time and Termites

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Wednesday that New York City public schools would immediately begin to use student test scores as a factor in deciding which teachers earn tenure, a proposal that has been bitterly opposed by the teachers' union and criticized as putting too much weight on standardized exams. The city already uses test scores in
title: Mayor to Link Teacher Tenure To Test Scores

body: THE chef King Phojanakong certainly has the frontier spirit. It's been six years since he set up shop in a tenement on the then-forlorn Lower East Side, serving ambitious, idiosyncratic Asian fare at Kuma Inn. Reachable only by a vertiginous stair, it has always had a scrappy vibe, like a speak-easy meant for quick disassembly. Last year, Mr.
title: $25 AND UNDER; Comfort Food the Southeast Asian Way

body: Since March, The Times has run two hyper-local blogs, one about Brooklyn and one about New Jersey, creating virtual community hubs where neighbors report on their own neighborhoods. A regular feature on The Local is a virtual ''fridge'' displaying children's art, held up with digital magnets. ''We promise they won't fall off when the magnets get
title: BLOGOSPHERE | THE FRIDGE; On a Digital Refrigerator, an Art Gallery for the Young

body: AT the charmingly retro Waverly Restaurant on the Avenue of the Americas in Greenwich Village, not to be confused with the stridently exclusive Waverly Inn nearby, a color headshot of one of the best-known legal figures of the 20th century hangs on the wall. His name was William M. Kunstler, and this celebrated civil rights lawyer, who for nearly
title: FILM; Filmmakers' Controversy: Their Dad

body: A gunman in a sport utility vehicle opened fire on a group of people standing in a Brooklyn deli on Friday night, sending three people -- one of them a pregnant woman -- to a local hospital with gunshot wounds, the police said. The drive-by shooting at 7 p.m. in Clinton Hill turned a routine gathering of regulars at a neighborhood deli into a scene
title: 3 Wounded in Drive-By Shooting at Brooklyn Deli

body: BIG cities like New York are both deeply convenient -- two steps to the deli for milk in the morning -- and deeply inconvenient. It is possible to live in the same city as the person you are dating, and have to travel an hour, or even two, to get together. Those long subway rides are so annoying that they shape not only dating patterns, but real
title: When Love Is a Schlep

body: THE religion of Southern fried chicken is spreading fast in New York City, with pilgrims making stops at the Redhead in the East Village, Locanda Verde in TriBeCa and Buttermilk Channel in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. But while adherents may argue about buttermilk or brine, batter or dredge and shallow fry or deep fry, dissenters say there's a more
title: Fried Chicken: A Migratory Bird

body: The museum in the private house near the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway announces itself in blue letters spelled out in painter's masking tape. ''Don't let Pirate Mike steal our heritage,'' reads the sign, above a row of illustrations of gorgeous brick-fronted mansions and the legend ''Landmark Admiral's Row.'' Not much more information is forthcoming
title: WALLABOUT JOURNAL; A Museum of Stuff, but Also of a Mission to Still the Wrecking Ball

body: Through the building frenzy that transformed some of the city's long-neglected patches into lustrous new neighborhoods, few frontiers struggled to reap the benefits of gentrification more than working-class Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. Prices of homes rose, but never as much as in Fort Greene. Its long-neglected brownstones attracted renovators
title: Amid a Citywide Slump, a Local Exception

author: Ava Chin, a professor of creative nonfiction and journalism at the College of Staten Island-CUNY, writes regularly about urban foraging on The Local.
body: I WAS walking in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, near the Outpost Cafe on Fulton Street, when I noticed that the mugwort plants on the block had gone to seed and become quite rangy. Then I discovered an odor and a fan-shaped leaf under my clogs. This is how you usually find ginkgo. You're ambling innocently along a city block enjoying one of those lovely
title: BLOGOSPHERE URBAN FORAGER; What's That Smell? Hello, Ginkgo

title: City Seeks to Turn Stalled Projects Into Moderate-Income Housing

title: LIVING IN | BEDFORD-STUYVESANT, BROOKLYN; History, With Hipper Retailing and Fewer Hazards

body: THE signs of a nascent coup in an apartment building are unmistakable. An anonymous letter filled with angry accusations gets slipped under apartment doors. Clutches of residents whisper in the lobby. And then there's the knock on the door, followed by hushed but urgent pleading for a vote to unseat, or maybe keep, a certain board member. Many
title: The Co-op Board Wars

body: For three weeks in July, The Local, a New York Times blog about Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, ran a photojournalism workshop for six students, ages 10 to 12. Using donated cameras, the students documented their lives and street goingson, while also learning about technique, from focusing to Photoshop. One day, Syreeta McFadden of the Fort
title: ALBUM | NEW LENSES; Future Photojournalists, and What They Learned

body: DMC USA D.J. FINALS Beck and Kanye West are musicians who on the surface have little in common. Beck is a subgenre-hopping rock musician who first gained notice with the depression-inducing song ''Loser,'' while Kanye West's real-life chest-thumping boasts are almost as memorable as those in his rhymes. But when looking for accompaniment to their
title: Spare Times

body: Open Now PERMANENT BRUNCH After a yearlong gestation, Lesly Bernard's all-day brunch restaurant opened on July 26 for dinner. Brunch service starts Aug. 1. The menu includes butter-poached shrimp and grits; baked eggs with short rib ragù; and braised mushrooms with Salvatore ricotta and poached egg. The consulting chef is Meg Grace of Redhead
title: Off the Menu

body: VALISA AND JAMES TATE were among the first residents to move into One Brooklyn Bridge Park, a condominium project in Brooklyn Heights, in the summer of 2008. A year later, the hallways still feel barren. Only 77 of the building's 438 apartments have closed. Twenty-six are in contract. In order to keep money coming in during a difficult time for
title: Renters to the Rescue

title: ABOUT NEW YORK; Fuller Measure Of a Man Shot to Death By the Police

title: Gotta Move, Gotta Sell

title: Man Fatally Shot in Fight With Officer

body: It was Saturday morning, Louis Armstrong was growling a jazz standard, and sunlight sneaked in through golden-draped windows. title: BLOGOSPHERE BROOKLYN ON THE BAYOU; Weekend Chefs, Conjuring New Orleans

body: BROOKLYN'S PLACE In the Beer World For a while, the beer flowed from Brooklyn as if from a broken spigot. title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

title: 4-Story Brooklyn Building Under Repair Collapses

body: THERE were hives to inspect and honeycombs to drain, but before all that Patrick Gannon sat on a cinder block in his backyard on City Island with his 9-year-old son, Julian, and just watched the bees. title: SUMMER RITUALS | URBAN BEEKEEPING; Beekeepers Keep the Lid On

body: On a rainy morning in April, Lisa Feuer took the subway to the Brooklyn Dojo, a martial-arts studio where she was scheduled to teach a mommy-baby yoga class. title: What happened to all those liberated, self-reliant, self-branded free agents?

title: ART; A Confidence Highlighted In Rhinestones

title: THE SELL | PROSPECT HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; Listening to Your Broker Can Pay Off

title: ON THE HOMEFRONT; After The Bubble

body: IF ever there was a time for Fort Greene, one of the most revered brownstone districts in Brooklyn, to have an identity crisis, that time would be now. Fort Greene is Brooklyn's latest culinary mecca, bewitching foodies with hip, minimalist restaurants. Or it's a bastion of African-American pride and culture, a historic home to a vibrant community
title: LIVING IN | FORT GREENE, BROOKLYN; Multiple Identities Can Be a Good Thing

title: SPARE TIMES

title: ON NYTIMES.COM

body: When it comes to the restaurant scene in Brooklyn, Clinton Hill may be overshadowed by its neighbors Fort Greene and Williamsburg. title: GOOD EATING/CLINTON HILL; Flavors of Brooklyn

body: IN 1974 Tehching Hsieh, a young Taiwanese performance artist working as a seaman, walked down the gangplank of an oil tanker docked in the Delaware River and slipped into the United States. His destination: Manhattan, center of the art world. Once there, though, Mr. Hsieh found himself ensnared in the benumbing life of an illegal immigrant. With
title: ART; A Caged Man Breaks Out at Last

body: The Clinton Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn thuds to a halt at Atlantic Avenue; Prospect Heights starts a few blocks south. But now there is a storefront between gas stations and warehouses there that looks as if it were transported intact from Paris. Choice Atlantic, its burgundy facade lettered à la Française, is a new food store owned by Thierry
title: FOOD STUFF; Food on a Grand Scale

body: Information about events to be considered for inclusion in Spare Times can be sent to weekend@nytimes.com. body: CLINTON HILL 3-FAMILY $1,775,000 BROOKLYN: 436 Classon Avenue (near Gates Avenue) A four-story Greek Revival house with a front porch, a side driveway, a garage and a backyard. The owner's garden duplex has two bedrooms and two baths; the two rentals have a bedroom and a bath each. Suzanne DeBrango, Ian Johnson, Brooklyn Properties (718) 532-1234;
title: ON THE MARKET

body: Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music. GABRIEL ALEGRÍA AFRO-PERUVIAN SEXTET (Thursday) On a sharp recent album, ''Nuevo Mundo'' (Saponegro), the trumpeter and composer Gabriel Alegría teases out affinities between modern jazz and the African-influenced coastal music of his native Peru. title: Spare Times

body: Opening This Week LA FONDA DEL SOL Long before Latino food was a trend, Joseph Baum offered it in the Time & Life building in Rockefeller Center. Now his 1960s restaurant there has been reborn in the MetLife building. Its chef, Josh DeChellis, formerly of Sumile, Jovia and Bar Fry, is creating fairly straightforward Spanish tapas and larger plates.
title: Off the Menu

body: It would be easy for most people to walk past the green, boarded-up, graffiti-laden storefront on Bedford Avenue, near Quincy Street, in Brooklyn without so much as a second look -- or the stoop in front of 918 Fulton Street, or the bodega half a block away at the corner of Washington Avenue. Not for Lil' Cease. A stroll through the neighborhood,
title: A Film Captures Bed-Stuy as It Was

body: IN the gym of Boys and Girls High School in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, on Monday night, as a thunderous version of the soul hit ''Ain't No Stoppin' Us Now'' echoed off the walls, Tyrone Brown, director of the Brooklyn Steppers, stood at the front of the room and scrutinized his charges. Some 90 young instrumentalists dressed in yellow T-shirts
title: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT; A Bed-Stuy Band Prepares for a Brush With History

body: THREE KINGS DAY The lights have been taken down, the trees are on the way to the mulch pile, and Christmas cards are being offered at staggering discounts, but holiday celebrations aren't over yet.
